Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Minimally Invasive and Standard Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Fifty-two patients were randomised to receive either MIS or standard TKA.

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults eligible for TKA, matched for age, weight, height, BMI, sex, and surgically treated side.

Intervention.evidence: Fifty-two patients were randomised to receive either MIS or standard TKA.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates whether MIS TKA results in greater knee strength compared to standard TKA.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was knee extensor torque, measured preoperatively and at 8 weeks postoperatively using isokinetic tests.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty-two patients were randomised to receive either MIS or standard TKA.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 8 weeks, mean postoperative extensor torques were 47 Nm for MIS and 45 Nm for standard TKA.

Trial_Registration.evidence: The study was registered under trial number [insert trial registration number].

Funding.evidence: Funding was provided by [insert funding source].
